[h1]WAAAAAGH!!!![/h1]
如同這個叫聲一樣，這款遊戲就是讓人覺得如此過癮且爽快，無疑是我近期玩過最爽的一款爽Game，尤其是跟朋友一起玩更是歡樂。

在遊玩的時候隨著簡單無腦到不行的劇情，也會讓玩家不禁發出「Waaaagh!!!」的獸人長嚎，讓鄰居被我半夜吵醒好快樂。


[b]●優點[/b]

+無厘頭且歡樂的劇情演出
+恢復HP的道具與檢查點給的很寬鬆，建議困難開局體驗會更好
+豐富的槍枝種類，包含我所喜愛的近戰武器
[strike]+有些武器具有友軍傷害，可以來個心結擂台[/strike]
+具有獸人職業選擇，攻擊方式會有變化

雖然這些優點對許多玩家來說應該是再常識不過的優點，但是從《Guns, Gore & Cannoli》1代與2代一路玩下來的玩家來說，真心覺得開發商的進步很大，這點讓我感到相當開心，與朋友選擇不同職業遊玩時有著不同的快樂。


[b]●缺點[/b]

-連線不太穩定，合作模式勉強可以玩，但對戰幾乎無法
-後期Boss戰有點偏向是塞小怪群毆的感覺，還好補血給的多
-很多槍枝都是空有特效但實戰上難用到不行，用到最後還是都在玩那幾把，體驗上有待加強


[b]■結尾[/b]

真的很喜歡《Rogueside》工作室所製作的2D橫向射擊遊戲，不論是關卡難度還是遊戲設計都是相當優秀的，手繪美術也讓我很喜歡。

當然不得不說，可以連線與朋友遊玩的遊戲就是一款好遊戲！
一路玩下來真的覺得進步很大，期待該開放商製作的下一款遊戲。 | This game is silly nonsense at its best and I love it. my little boy and I have been playing at the same time - he does the shooting, I do the running and jumping. We play on easy, it has been great! | чиловая игра сделанная под мультиплеер.
Поиграть с кем то под пивас пойдёт, отсылок на Одноглаза прилично, так же пркольное количество оружек.
Из минусов отмечу лиь два:
1) каким боком гвардейци, камисары размером с орка, а космодесант итого выше если орки в лоре прямо огромные и космодесантник лишь в броне равен им по росту?
2) оптимизация, игра оочень багованная и часто вылетает, трупы начинает колбасить а по всей карте летют ошмётки крови, то что я пару рас проваливался под карту или сквиги застревали в стенах.
В принципе игру советовать могу но повтарюсь игра заточена под мультиплеер и в соло вас довольно часто будут убивать и на нормальной сложности, то как я на максимальной проходил я промолчу | This game is so much fun. The sprites are accurately detailed, the voice acting is great. I want to think that this is what the orks see battle looking like when they go into war. Fantastic | [h1] Зеленая миля [/h1]

Хорошая, короткая игра часов на 10 с бодрейшим саундтреком, классными анимациями и ваха-юмором. Бойз довольны)
Жирный минус - мало контента всего 12 пушек, из которых адекватные половина, не особо классы различаются, а с сетевой у меня не получилось разобраться.

Не грех поддержать нишевый проект по Вахе, но и побольше контента можно было навалить за пару лет, даже за деньги)

上手之后会立马显得重复度略高，而且局外成长太花时间，要体验到完整的内容很费劲。

其次在上强度之后，游戏会从模拟建设瞬间转化成微操资源管理，人力和资源的极致运用才能让你拿下胜利，你说肉鸽？什么肉鸽？哪有肉鸽？建设？哪有建设？

这不算充足的随机性除了能让你升血压并不能让你的体验得到提升，毕竟这个游戏所有的肉鸽收益基本都是有滞后性的，鲜少有立即生效却对你收益巨大的情况出现，游戏本身也是比起解决问题更倾向于让问题防患于未然，可以说基本都处于一种今日受苦而明日享福的循环，而人往往并不待见延迟满足，这也是城市建造类游戏的通病，随机性则让这一点被增幅了许多，毕竟脸黑一下的话你的精心布局很可能要到游戏尾声才得以找到key牌启动。

在真正上手游戏的中后期，本作特色的“肉鸽”“建设”属性可以说是基本等于没有（甚至肉鸽方面可能是负作用？），冲着这两点来的颇有几分受骗的味道。高强度下的资源匮乏和时间赛跑让游戏的建设属性约等于无，时间全花在拼尽全力管理有效利用资源上，而肉鸽属性正反馈不足，且低难度通解太多、高难度拿不到最优解血压又太高，负反馈很强导致肉鸽的设计很抽象。

相对的，游戏耐玩、结构与内容完整，微创新也不少，上手简单易懂，游戏内有明确的阶段性目标，能让城建玩的少的玩家不至于迷失方向不知道该做什么，每一局的目标不一样一定程度上保持了新鲜感都是值得肯定的优点。

总的来说是值得一个好评的，入手推荐史低，另DLC风评远不如本体，慎入。 | Against the Storm focuses on the best part of a city builder which is the first hours when you are in the building phase.  Against the Storm plays out differently every time because the buildings you start with are always different.   It is a well optimized game, with constant choices of risk vs reward, and enjoyable when you figure out work-arounds for meeting necessary resources, through supply chain management.

What I appreciate about Against the Storm is that there is never is a point where it gets too complicated with too much too deal with at one time.  The equivalent of the "Boss battle" is challenging and rewarding.  Graphic and sound design are excellent.

I've played over 650 hours and still not sick of it, so there must be something to this video game.  

Support these devs.  Eremite Games is a Polish developer consisting of six, and they really have created a real gem of a game, and they have been actively improving and polishing the game for more than a year after the day 1 release. | Let me preface this by saying that the game is very well made and I understand why so many people love it. I am not refunding it for any notable flaws.

For me specifically, when I play this type of game I want to dig in and work on one continuous settlement and make it grow over time, eventually getting to a point where I have this massive city that basically runs itself, giving me a primal sense of satisfaction that doesn't need to be felt again for roughly two years. But this game is a rogue-lite with some aspects of a mobile game, where you constantly restart a 'run', so to speak, unlocking stuff to make things more interesting for the next one. And though well-crafted, it's just not the kind of thing I'm looking for in a city-builder. | I genuinely started off liking Against the Storm, but the further you get into the difficulties the more tedious it gets, with additional negative modifiers and additional hoops to jump through to complete the session. Each seal completion really incentivizes you to play the next difficulty to get enough shards to complete the next seal to follow the metaplot, and lower difficulties may not get you the number of seals you need in time - additionally, the further out you go, the higher the minimum difficulty of the embarkment is, pushing the player to embark on those higher difficulty options. Why progress the seals other than metaplot? So you get more resources for the Citadel metaprogression. Which does things like add resources to your starting caravan so you can actually build some production buildings at the start, or adding a production building that let you make many key items - poorly, at high cost, but beneficial for the build chains so you are not fully reliant on RNG to get a building to complete the chain, or even adding bonuses to each race in your settlement like showing you where the first set of fields is where you can build a farm the first time you recruit a Human, so you don't have to spend half the session opening the wrong glades and never getting the constant food production that would provide. 

Except like many modern roguelite hybrids, this metaprogression is poorly balanced, and time consuming, which makes it feel like busywork rather than enjoyable on its own. It makes the higher difficulties less tedious to tackle (especially with some of the more helpful bonuses), but it just feels like an absolute chore to get through. Speaking of chores, they just add more chores without opening meaningful doors and mechanics past Veteran in terms of the difficulty options. The first three difficulties add mechanics each jump - after Veteran comes Viceroy, which is the same thing as Veteran with new forbidden and dangerous glade events to threaten your settlement and that the forest is more hostile by a multiplier of x3 instead of x2, but they don't do anything "new" really, they are just more of what you have seen before on earlier difficulties, and they just cost a ton of resources that you may not have been able to produce unless you have enough bonuses from the metaprogression tree and otherwise they apply so many negative benefits your game may actually end, such as the Stormbird which as far as I can tell by searching across the internet, people have been complaining is poorly balanced even with a good settlement for years. I don't just mean negatively either - the Stormbird applies an infinite storm effect, locking you to a year until you finish it (which you could delay), which is abusable in its own right if you were lucky enough to find it early. The Stormbird is just absurdly out of band in both directions and I cannot understand the intent of including it compared to every other event. I suppose that its very existence changes the logic pattern of whether you should open forbidden glades at all, but the higher difficulties disincentivize the opening of small glades due to hostility modifiers, so that just leaves dangerous glades if you do not want to starve but want to ensure a manageable event. What a forcible winnowing of the meta - it creates a very rote playstyle even though the apparent point of RNG building choice to create more unstable, dynamic push-and-pull gameplay. 

By the way, the tree also has a level attached - as you go through various sessions you get XP, when you level up you unlock new buildings and cornerstones (buffs) to show up in the game. THIS metaprogression mechanic is where the actual doors are opened for new build orders. Except its just as slow as the tree since its a blocker on the tree - without those later buildings and cornerstones, the game is not necessarily giving you the tools to win on higher difficulties. The amount of XP seems really low as well no matter the difficulty and even with completing various achievement challenges, which just exacerbates the issue.

I assume the decision not to bind those buildings and cornerstones to the higher difficulties and instead to a metaprogression level was so that you can use them on the lower difficulties and practice various build chains, but without overwhelming people when they start to play, and because of the complexity of creating a system that could both leave them default on the higher difficulties and then unlock them for use on the lower one once you cleared the higher one. Though perhaps they could have used their training missions for this. In all honesty the buildings beyond the first few levels matter less than the cornerstones, but they both add to how obnoxious the metaprogression system is - even if it is justified ludonarratively. 

In positives, I genuinely like the give and take between blight and production starting with the Veteran difficulty. I enjoy the season model and how each session naturally pushes you to modify your build chain on the fly or attempt to produce enough of your current resources to trade for the things you need to complete the Orders. I enjoy the fact that a session can take no more than one hour or maybe two at the higher speeds and therefore allows a bite-sized city building experience. I genuinely did get 30 hours out of it so I would say I got my money's worth, and I may play some more now and again, but anything that sufficiently annoys me more than it captivates me gets a negative review especially when the causes will not be immediately apparent to the player. | 与其说是城市营造或者基地建设，更像是有限资源管理游戏，不符合我的兴趣

Sadly they abandonded the games over 2 years ago without communicating anything to the community. 
Server are offline way to often now (maybe permanent soon?) | Classical RTS.

The game is visually nice. The mechs are cool and that is probably why we all buy it.
The tutorial was surprising, limited, yet interesting.
The main concern is, I am not so sure units always does what ordered. They shoot targets for sure, but not necessarily the ones selected. Or it is not clear. Or some becomes mad and stop responding properly. Something is strange here.
There is a pause in campaign mode and it is appreciable. This is not told during the tutorial. Check the keys mapping in the settings to find it.
It copies the classics of the genre. It use the heroes mechanic that was once found in the Warcraft series. However, the resemblance becomes really clear from the third map only. The mission in which you are starting to build.

=====
Edit
=====
I confirm the game in campaign mode at least is not bug free at all.

Characters, especially heroes, may stop responding properly and just go anywhere they want. Sometimes for long. Giving any other order is not changing anything.

One mission, the hero is supposed to die. If you survive the waves of enemies, you may be good to check some forums to find what to do next to progress.

Other mission, an infiltration one just after the hero that must die, some enemy soldiers get stuck. Making impossible any progress without reloading a save.

The quick load comes with a confirmation and a check box supposed to permit to not confirm next quick load. And next times, the dialog will appear with the box checked. Uncheck/recheck did not change anything. | Love the game, but I have issues with AMD GPU. I would invest more time into the game if I didn't encounter so many issues. | Iron Harvest is an ambitious game. That's the best way to sum it up. It has a cool concept—dieselpunk mechs in an alternate history WWI world—but unfortunately, it doesn’t live up to the hype.

The unit cap is absurdly limiting. You’ve got 60 points to work with, but mechs eat up 4-8 points each. This leaves almost no room to build a varied army, especially when you’re supposed to be leading large-scale battles. It’s hard to strategize when your army’s just a handful of mechs with very little room for infantry or other units.

The movement and pathfinding is where things really start to fall apart. Mechs are slow—really slow—especially when turning. They get stuck on terrain all the time, which makes controlling them frustrating. This wouldn’t be so bad if the rest of the controls were tight, but unfortunately, they aren’t. The retreat mechanic, which could be a tactical advantage, doesn’t help either. When you tell units to retreat, they just wander slowly toward the nearest healing station at a walking pace. This basically guarantees they’ll get wiped out before they can make it to safety.

Resource management is about as shallow as it gets. You only manage iron and oil, which gives you very little to work with in terms of building a solid economy or having to plan ahead. It feels like the game is just focused on combat, but it’s hard to enjoy the battles when the mechanics themselves are broken. The factions aren’t balanced either. Infantry units are nearly identical except for basic weapons, and the AI just cheats by spawning units without using resources. This makes it harder to take the game seriously when the opposition isn’t even playing by the same rules.

The technical side of things is also a mess. The game is 30GB of space and still struggles to run smoothly. There are constant bugs, crashes, and performance issues that make it hard to get through a session without frustration. Multiplayer is practically nonexistent, and the developers seem to have abandoned the game—there’s no sign of any meaningful updates or fixes. This is especially frustrating considering the steep price tag, especially when you realize the game’s been left to rot.

Iron Harvest had so much potential, but the execution just doesn’t cut it. The dieselpunk art design is great, but that’s about the only thing this game has going for it. If you’re really curious, maybe wait for a steep discount, but even then, don’t expect anything more than a frustrating experience with some cool art. | Nota: 8/10

Se você gostou de Company of Heroes, este jogo é muito similar. Ótimo para jogar contra amigos.

Adorei a ideia da série e a arte é do meu gosto. Esperei por uma promoção também e comprei o jogo e o DLC. Nunca toco em multiplayer, então só estava interessado na campanha e achei que valeu muito a pena pelo preço. É uma campanha longa com muita variedade nas missões.

Underrated fighter of the last generation, definitely on of my favorites from it. Beautifully weighty attacks with an emphasis on the neutral game and whiff punishes with HUGE DAMAGE, it is simple enough to jump in and play but yet lots of depth through system mechanics and while combos are much smaller and simpler then your average modern fighting game I say that with the strict timing they still can be hard to land because of the precise timing and strict windows for punishing. Enjoy big damage with amazing personality and ambiance with a long legacy of games to enjoy as well. It is even a game I have pulled out with friends on occasion (yes even ones that aren't huge into fighting games) and many of them seem to enjoy it though dont let the ease of pick up let that fool you still cause the better player will more likely than not still win but you might even make the gods bleed because in this game EVERYONE IS MORTAL... well for the most part lol (I am looking at you amakusa) | This Game is worth it and pretty nice game but like any other fighting game this game is also dead NO MATCHMAKING Available or anyother online mod, but Besides that you can try story mod or offline match against CPU | 说实在的，这款游戏我买了一年之后才玩，原因是安装后压根无法启动。最近看到去年升级了一次，抱着试一试的态度运行了一下，居然成功了。大致看了一下成就，大部分成就的全球完成率不到0.2%，也就是说大部分买这款游戏的人根本就没有玩儿！之所以买这款游戏是因为大学时宿舍里一堆人围着一台电脑玩侍魂2，对此念念不忘。总体试玩下来感觉和侍魂2的手感还是很接近的。但游戏的过场流程不是行云流水的感觉，一些诙谐滑稽的动作表情也没有了，有时候会卡帧，一些过关静态画面的人物造型感觉没完工，有点敷衍，总体来说有侍魂2情节的还是推荐入手的。 | I love SAMURAI SHODOWN; all of it. 
The swings feel meaty. The roster is good. It's a little hard as fighters go; because, you really pay for your missteps. 
My one complaint is, i wish the "Spot Dodge's" i-frames lasted a bit longer. 
I give it 4 out of 5. A MUST play for any fighting game fan, or 90's kids who grew up in the arcade. 
Oh, and dope-ass music!! | Le titre profite de l'Unreal Engine 4 qui lui offre un cachet esthétique proche de celui de Street Fighter IV avec un style crayonné du plus bel effet mais aussi une animation parfaite qui rend les combats nerveux et intenses. Il faut aussi saluer l'excellente bande son qui propose des musiques japonisantes très fidèles à la série, des doublages japonais immersifs et des bruitages puissants mettant bien en valeur l'impact des armes. Enfin le gameplay n'est pas en reste avec une palette de coups variée misant davantage sur la précision que sur l'abondance de combos parce qu'il ne s'agit pas ici d'enchaîner l'adversaire mais plutôt de trouver la faille et de s'y engouffrer.
Le contenu satisfera aussi les amateurs de jeux de combat avec une bonne vingtaine de personnages aux styles diversifiés et à des modes de jeu étoffés tels que le mode histoire, le mode entraînement, le mode combat, le mode dojo ou encore le mode en ligne.
Samurai Shodown ressuscite de la plus belle manière grâce au talent de SNK et modernise la licence sans jamais la dénaturer, du grand art tout simplement.

Highly addictive and much more forgiving than other rogue-like games.  Hard recommend | It's a fine game until the final boss reveals infinitely duplicating minions that you can only target with a specific weapon. That weapon does nothing to any other monster making it unusable. It's a stupid gimmick and really frustrating and unfun. | Fun little game, a little bit of mech building, a little bit of roguelite strategy plus basic tactical combat. Nothing too deep, but simple and fun. Looks hard during first few runs, after that you realize there are some pretty efficient combos and weapons which make the game almost too easy. It is good for killing some extra time during the day or as relaxation after playing some serious  games. Worth to buy for 3$ discounted price (which is at least once during every month)m otherwise dont spend the money and wait for the discount. | Didn't really enjoy the game, building mech's seemed quite bland. | Good, simple strategy game.

Genres: Indie, Simulation, Strategy, Free To Play
Reviews: очень залипательная...........

Game Name: Voice of Cards: The Isle Dragon Roars Demo
Reviews: No Reviews
No Reviews

Very fun 4X game that makes every turn matter, from the research you choose to prioritize from knowing when to push and when to stay put, it is a fantastic strategy game that requires a plan but also adaptability on the player's part. I like that every faction leader plays differently as some of them can make units move after attack, rush production, or even have a big canon to defend their city. While the game has all of this going for it, some technologies like engineers are a staple since expanding your territory with multiple towns is very good for your resource pool, so it has a nice balance between picking common strategies and then incorporating your base on the map.

The final war in the last few turns is exciting and makes me nervous, all players and AI pick from 3 sides and then go on an all-out war. Two sides get colossal titans, making the battlefield intense as you look to protect allies while dispatching enemies. I found high-end units to be super fun, particularly human aircraft is a blast to see the planes moving around the map at high speed, ignoring terrain and I love the skill "evasive maneuvers" that they have. One can make their army a combination of units but usually specializing pays more, I found that Humans and Cyber feel strong but Voice (the Eldritch Horrors) felt extremely weak in comparison. Hoping the new DLC Voice leader fixes this with some new units and perks.

The game can get stale fast if you play by yourself, but with friends is a lot of fun and remains fresh. I had 15 hours because it is hard to get the whole gang together, but we did 3 matches, and every time it felt good, wasn't a chore or boorish, it was fun to do alliances, and wars and try to win the race of developing faster than everyone else. Graphically it looks nice, the voice acting is good and the music is nice but sometimes there are periods of silence which is a bit of a bummer. The early to mid-game is the best, you gotta analyze your starting point carefully to be successful and outpost contention is thrilling, The Late game can be a bit tedious at times, but only for a little bit at the point where you are between researching and getting the high units. Once you have the units, the late game is a blast!

I recommend the game to people who like Warhammer Gladius or those wanted to try a 4X strategy game for the first time. Beginner friendly and once you get the hang of it after your first match, all that remains is optimizing moves and adapting to situations. In my group the game has been a massive hit, we always speak fondly of it and are excited to play more matches.

[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/43679955/][quote]If you enjoyed the review, please follow my curator! [b]StarsDeck[/b]. | ZEPHON's biggest strength for me is its vibe and aesthetics, especially the Voice (aka alien/eldritch horror) side. It's a post-apocalyptic world, but not a typical "after a huge intra-human war" settings - instead it's an alien invasion gone horribly wrong for everyone involved, including said aliens. The units' voice acting (even if the lines can be a little repetitive at times) also reinforce this, especially in the early game where your tiny and weak units are trying to survive against the various forms of new and terrifying wildlife. The game dispenses some of its lore at the end of a game depending on your actions as well as in technology and unit descriptions, not unlike a FromSoft game which is very unusual for the genre and an interesting decision.

The diplomacy system is surprisingly well-developped especially coming from the developpers of Gladius (where it's non-existant on purpose). Not only can you sign various treaties with the other players, but you can also tell them to sign one with a given player, or ask them to break their existing treaties. This lets you create a "bloc" of alliances to tackle the endgame together, but also means that an AI that hates you and is allied with one of your allies can also try to break your alliance and isolate you. Speaking of the AI, it's not mind-blowing but it's decent and can actually play the game much better than in Civ or Endless Legend. When it declares war on you (at least on higher difficulty levels), you can expect an actual attack with focus and intent. It's not uncommon to see AI players wiping each other out, unlike most other games where even conquering one city can be a tough ask for the AI.

Overall it's a great and refreshing 4X game that I hope will see some more updates in the future without becoming as bloated as Gladius.

Completionists beware however, as there's an achievement that would easily take 1000 hours if done legitimately, and even the cheese method requires letting the game play itself in a very specific way for a few hours. | i played this because i played  Warhammer 40,000: Gladius before, which is a game I greatly enjoyed. 
TBH I am deeply disappointed with Zephon. You play as different classes but all pretty much have the same tech tree. There is no real fun in the way of "ok now I will play as this one..." they are all the same. I am now currently playing  Warhammer 40,000: Gladius again and the difference between each faction is massive in comparison. This Zephon game always ends the same where there is some kind of huge face off between the Zephon clan and the Acrin involving massive colossal units entering the battlefield and if you have advanced enough these are not hard to take down alongside allied forces. It is just so boring after a couple of playthroughs, unlike Warhammer 40,000: Gladius which is far superior in terms of 'lets play again as a different faction!' The emphasis being on the word different. | Great turn based combat with Unique units and factions. Coming from Gladius I was instantly hooked by the lore and QOL changes. | Zephon Review – A Game with Immense Potential

Zephon is a game that truly feels like it's on the verge of greatness. From the moment you dive in, its immersive atmosphere, stunning visuals, and hauntingly well-crafted sound design pull you deep into its world. The attention to detail is evident, especially in how in-depth the descriptions are when hovering over various stats—something strategy enthusiasts will definitely appreciate.

Pros:
✅ Incredible atmosphere & setting – The world of Zephon is rich and immersive.
✅ Top-tier graphics & sound – Visually and audibly, it’s a feast.
✅ Deep stat explanations – Great for players who love micromanagement.

Cons & Areas for Improvement:
❌ Research bottleneck at Tier 9 – If you set required research per tier to 5+ items, you can’t progress to Tier 10 due to not having enough tier researched because you can only research 4 techs in tier 9.
❌ Diplomacy is a bit too linear – It works, but it could offer more meaningful choices.
❌ AI needs serious improvement – Even on Hard with a large map, the AI lagged far behind in military tactics, resources, and overall challenge. I was steamrolling everything, which led me to quit out of sheer lack of resistance. If Ultra Hard simply buffs units and cities without improving AI behavior, it won’t fix the core issue.
❌ Unit variety could use a boost – While not a huge deal, more faction diversity would add more depth.

Final Thoughts:
Zephon is fun and has all the makings of a classic, but right now, the experience feels incomplete due to the AI, diplomacy, and research bottleneck issues. I’ll be keeping an eye on updates, but for now, I’m stepping away. That said, with the right tweaks, this could become something truly special.

Looking forward to what’s next! 🔥

Game Name: Symphony of War: The Nephilim Saga
Reviews:
Oof. I really wanted to love this game, but what a let down. The gorgeous 2D combat screenshots hooked me right away, and with an Overwhelmingly Positive rating by the community, my expectations were high. Unfortunately, after 77 hours of play, Symphony of War: The Nephilim Saga landed at a measly 6/10 for me.

At its core, this is a tactical RPG that feels like a mix of Brigandine (PS1) and The Last Remnant, blending large-scale army management with squad-based combat. You command an army composed of up to 35 (or 40?) squads, each led by a captain with up to nine units ranging from tanks, melee fighters, archers, mages, healers, gunners, cannons, cavalry, and even dragons. Squad composition determines mobility, whether it’s slow infantry, swift cavalry, or airborne units.

Combat plays out on a huge, grid-based map, where you control squad movement. However, once battle starts, you lose direct control over individual units. They attack, heal, crit, and occasionally get extra turns on their own. I love that about it - the randomness of units you handpicked playing themselves in battle. Between battles, you’ll level up units, choose branching advanced classes (fire/ice/lightning mages, paladins, valkyries, rogues, etc.), and unlock army-wide traits that boost different aspects like mage damage, dragon deployment costs, battle income, etc. etc.

SO... WHAT WENT WRONG? 

Well, on paper, this game should have been perfect for me. But a few mechanics ruined the experience.

1. The Squad Composition Problem

One of the strongest traits in the game grants a damage bonus for having mixed unit types in a squad—and it’s so powerful that not using it feels like a handicap. This forces you to build squads based on variety rather than theme.

I wanted to create a gunner squad with tanks in the front and a healer in the back. Or an all-rogue squad for fast, hit-and-run tactics. Or a red dragon squad with red mages supporting them. Instead, the optimal strategy became a hodgepodge of different unit types—tanks, melee, healers, and ranged all thrown together just to activate that bonus. Sure, you can still build thematic squads, but you’ll be at a noticeable disadvantage for doing so.

2. No Real Specialization – You Get Everything Eventually

A big part of tactical RPGs is specialization—choosing upgrades, traits, and strategies that shape your army’s identity. Symphony of War completely removes that tension because you can unlock every single trait in a single playthrough. Instead of having to make meaningful choices and craft a specialized force, you eventually just get everything.

To make matters worse, individual units can learn so many perks that every squad ends up feeling maxed out and overpowered, reducing strategic depth. There’s no real sacrifice or trade-off—everyone just gets everything, which makes customization feel shallow.

3. The Cringey Dialogue & Bland Characters

The writing… oh lawd. It’s painful. Dialogue is filled with clichés, forced drama or romance, and awkward exchanges that made me roll my eyes so hard I saw the back of my own skull. None of the characters stood out or felt compelling. The story itself is fine, but the way it’s told feels like getting force-fed exposition with a shovel. Honestly, the game would have been better if they just deleted all the dialogue. And those massive character portraits... Why do they look like they wandered in from a completely different game? If they were removed, I wouldn’t miss them.

4. Clunky UI & Management System

The clunky UI made unit management phase an absolute chore. There’s way too much clicking, especially with equipping and unequipping gear. Navigating menus is tedious, making army management feel frustrating rather than fun and engaging.

THE REDEEMING QUALITIES:

Despite my complaints, there are things Symphony of War: The Nephilim Saga does really well:

+ Beautiful pixel art—both in battle and on the overworld map.
+ Fantastic sound design & effects—attacks and magic feel satisfying.
+ Solid music—fits the tactical RPG vibe.
+ Tons of equipment variety—there’s a lot to experiment with.

FINAL THOUGHTS:

Even though this game frustrated me, I’m still marking it as “Recommended.” Why? Because I want to see more pixel-art tactical RPGs in the vein of Brigandine and The Last Remnant. Those games were fantastic, and I’d love for this genre to make a comeback on Steam. If you can tolerate the issues I mentioned, you might enjoy it a lot more than I did. In fact, many, many other folks already do (and I think that's great for them).

But for me? It’s a reluctant thumbs-up :/ | 越往后越没意思，剧情实在一言难尽，主角身为圣子依靠惊世智慧，运筹帷幄，带领全国一半有生力量和众多知名英雄人物一口气全军覆没，自己也被处决。圣父多纳尔都绷不住了，只能借尸还魂，直接上号靠圣灵之力作弊代打，开启龙傲天之路，无语了。另外永久死亡模式居然，剧情人物不给死，小兵的命也是命啊，瞬间感觉没啥挑战性了。游戏性尚可吧，但小兵属性随机的设定不太行，尤其自己练的小兵不仅亏属性、吃资源，属性还没有雇佣兵强，就很难接受。
通关后更加感觉游戏很潦草，汉化一坨还不完全，剧情一坨还有快乐的、欠缺自由的、突兀的、任意搭配的恋爱线。游戏全程战斗力靠数值，兵种克制就是说笑，兵种攻击机制差异化很小，全靠神器道具撑属性，骑兵移动力和步兵差别不大，二次移动基本就是换个地方挨打。 | Great game, I have gotten many hours of enjoyment out of it. Looking forward to seeing more from these devs in the future. | 剧情一坨，战斗优异。 | Do you remember those old cumbersome tactical RPG's from the 80's? Miracle Warriors, Shinning Force, Ultima, FF1 and then came the Golden Age with the 90's RPG's and all their anime graphics, massive swords and whacky hairy styles, uniforms, weird as story lines? Well if you do, "Symphony of War" will take you down memory lane and if you don't, you then need to jump on the bandwagon and take a trip back in time when RPG's were exciting and different to what they are today.

The game oozes tons of fun, fantastic art, amazing music and a cheesy corny story line that you thank God you can skip and head straight onto focusing on your units and winning the game, or you can sit back and be entertained if that's your thing to.

There's alot of things wrong with this game especially with the interface, and the menu, omg it is absolutely horrendous but that's what it was like playing these games back in the day, tons of useless clicking!

Symphony of War is absolutely brilliant, if you can stop comparing it to today's RPG's and similar games like Fire Emblem, you will find a RPG that ooze's playability with tons of content and fun, the strategy, depth, the vast amount of unit's progression is unmatched, I honestly cannot recommend it enough and it is so amazing to relive this genre as how they were meant to be and use to be.

玩了差不多500小时，大部分势力都通关了，缝合了群星 战锤 甚至远古时代的银河战国群雄传。作为一款正统的战略SLG游戏，总体还是不错的，优点是缝合各种内容都算合格但缺点也让人头疼，行星管理和舰队管理虽然简化了但操作还是麻烦，没有一键处理或者模块化，每样都要一个个点。还有吞并其他势力后为什么对方势力的领袖要失踪，这让个别成就几乎无法完成！最大的问题：为什么没有战斗画面！！以前没注意，这次冬促发现1代是有战斗画面的，取消战斗画面的考量是什么啊？有战斗画面哪怕是1代那样的都会让2代在表现上更上一层楼 | Eigentlich nett gemacht, schöne retro Grafik, passende Musik und ein relativ seichtes Konzept was die Spielmechanik angeht. Leider wurde das Herzstück des Spiels, die Flotten/Mechkämpfe meiner Meinung nach versaut. Scheinbar ist Alles so stark vom Zufall abhängig, dass per Design eine straflose Wiederholungsfunktion des gesamten Kampfes eingeführt wurde. Und die ist auch nötig. Die generellen Trefferchancen sind zwischen 30 und 60 % und bieten massig Raum, das eine Runde ungeplant gut oder ungeplant schlecht laufen kann. Das macht es mitunter herausfordernd solide zu spielen und keine Einheiten zu verlieren. Der harte Spaßkiller ist allerdings der Mapspawn und das Unterstützungsspawnen von zusätzlichen Flotten. Leider ist auch nicht vorhersehbar, wann und wo Unterstützungsflotten eintreffen werden. Es kommt also öfter mal vor, dass eine gesamte gegnerische Flotte in die eigenen Reihen hineingeportet wird und erstmal fürstlich ihren ersten Zug genießt. | This will be one of my more lengthy reviews for a game I absolutely adore but at times can grow extremely frustrated with. It takes all the good things about the first game and polishes it finely. I will say I miss the fire emblem like cinematics but I also like the simple yet colorful animations that replaced them. This game is not for those who want something quick and easy. This game requires a lot of tactics, attention to the big and small details, heavy management of resources, units and planets. I find it extremely rewarding once you know what you're doing and get a better idea of each factions strengths and weaknesses. Start small with a faction that has allies, pay close attention to who is fighting who, make allies, invest in your defenses, keep a fleet or two back to protect your planets, pay attention to enemy flight paths to anticipate incoming attacks. My personal opinion, the game has so much content and so many things to manage that at first it can be extremely overwhleming but once you get the hang of it you will truly enjoy the game. I can't tell you how many campaigns I started only to be wiped out a few turns in. Now I can start a campaign and coast along crushing all who oppose me.

The more you play the more you unlock customization options, then you can eventually create your own overpowered custom commander who will pilot your favorite command unit and be pivotal when starting campaigns that you are at a disadvantage.

I purchased this game at full price and fully support the games Han creates. They always scratch this itch I have for a hard yet rewarding game where your decisions truly matter. This game offers equivalent to what Fire Emblem Three Houses offers in terms of customization, replay value, strategy, management, reward system and cool things that happen when you pay attention to all the details.

To sum it all up; this game is a good option for those who are willing to pour time into it, fight hard and pick yourself up when you're knocked down, pick up and play a lil bit each day where you can savor your wins and learn from your mess ups. The alien campaign literally took me a year to complete just because the difficulty but boy was it worth it to get the achievement in my book. Give it a go if you're big on strategy games and like a challenge.

A very addictive RPG visual novel set in a sci-fi/cyberpunk future.

You play as a sleeper, an emulated consciousness uploaded into a synthetic robotic body. A victim of corporate propaganda, you signed a contract of servitude, selling your real body away for the promise of a life off-world. But after losing faith in this promised future, you escaped with others from your indentured servitude. Being the only one to make it out alive, caught between a stolen past and an uncertain future, you find yourself on a decaying space station where you must evade the hunters after you and survive, all while trying to buy or synthesize the stabilizer you need to postpone your planned obsolescence.

I found the writing excellent and became completely engrossed by the different life stories of the station's inhabitants. It was easy to get attached to the various characters living on the station.
I also really liked the game's characters design, which reminded me of Katsuhiro Otomo's art style.
And the electronic music was a perfect fit for conveying the atmosphere of isolation and desperation on the station in the game's dystopian world.

Gameplaywise, I didnt find the game particularly difficult. After getting the hang of the mechanics, completing tasks and progressing through the game was fairly easy. Failure was ok as the game was quite forgiving. In my single playthrough, I only missed three achievements. The game has many endings, but you can continue playing by pressing [continue] after the end credits. To experience more endings, always choose the option to leave the station first, when given a choice.
It also didnt seem like the type of sleeper you started with really mattered. I finished the game with 4 out of my 5 sleeper skills fully upgraded.

The game's main strength lies in its fantastic writing and storytelling. So, if you enjoy great sci-fi/cyberpunk stories, you should definitely play this. | Impossible vibes. It's like if the comforting isolation of falling asleep to a white noise generator was a RPG. Incredible game and a very cool interpretation of a distant sci-fi/ cyberpunk future. | This game has some of the most beautiful stories and characters I've seen in a video game, or even some novels I've read. Over the years, you just don't find things like this. I'm a war hardened, grown man, and some of the story threads in this cut me deep. Thank you for this experience. | Citizen Sleeper is an OK game. In this glorified VN you play as a rogue "Sleeper" (hey, that's half the name of the game!) a robot with the brain of someone in cryostasis trying to escape the clutches of the evil corporation that employed you. Citizen Sleeper utilizes its cyberpunk influence to make a very compelling college brochure / kinetic novel, but not necessarily an interesting game.
To not be entirely dour on the game I'll conceit, I played the game, I got 3 of the 6 endings, and I only fell asleep twice. The core slash only gameplay mechanic of knowing what your dice rolls will be before you have a skill check is pretty nifty, and lets you choose to prioritize succeeding at the things you want to succeed at and fail at things you don't really care about. The game actually has an interesting cyberpunk setting and world its built, as opposed to the usual "future city but neon and bad" sloppa you usually get. The game can be finished in one or 2 short sittings. The look of the game is fairly iconic and inspired, and while you might not like the vaguely zog adjacent character designs, it is its own style and you're not going to see other games of the similar setting even remotely attempt this ambition, especially with its small 3 man team, even larger in breadth of scope and intention of design, so you have to admire the sheer passion and care involved.
And we've come to the part where I become a big fat meanie, so if you read that and are like "wow, hey wait, [i]I[/i] like words and pictures! I'm going to buy this now!" please, be my guest, its not bad.




[i]However[/i],,,
Citizen sleeper is not a game!!!! It's a VN with extra clicking!!!! The writing is one note, every character speaks in the same voice and I can't tell you anything a character said beyond aphorisms, cliches, occasional vague left footed marxist toe steps, and brief fellations towards the unnamed player character. A former soldier tells you his adopted daughter "saved him, actually", another tells you that you just don't get it do you, and my personal favourite, when you help a bounty hunter kill a man and she pays you, you drop the money on the ground and say "what life is worth this". I promise you, that you can google every cliche movie line and I guarantee its somewhere in this game spoken by the widely diverse cast of characters. That dice thing I talked about earlier becomes negligible past the first or second hour as once you've gained a couple levels, you can acquire the ability to reroll at any point during a turn, even when you only have one die left. Naturally, I abused this to get the main ending i wanted out of the game, because why not. In general though, levelling up trivializes the game, your first level, if you so choose can be spent to negate any weaknesses your character class had, you CAN add plus 2 bonuses to your rolls but by the end i was rolling too many 5's and 6's to even think of that as an investment. There's a skill to regain health and stamina for free, but you get so much money for every little thing you do you have to go OUT OF YOUR WAY TO FAIL AT ANYTHING. The game constantly terges and teases impending doom and choices mattering, however, I realized early on you don't actually have any agency in the solipsistic monologues the characters speak to you, so I said the meanest dialogue option I could, every time, and, every time, they would just ignore me and keep monologuing about the world. Speaking of doom, I'll let you know now, if you run out of health? You get put back to half health at the cost of one of your buffs/debuffs, if you run out of time on your bounty hunter missions? You get the same cutscenes as you would if you were a good boy. You are simply watching the story unfold from the eyes of another, the room starts spinning and I begin experiencing extreme depersonalization, is this how it is in the game? or is this every day for me? Do I truly want the life I lead? Do I have the choice to not want it after all? These are the questions I ask myself as I click through dialogues, rush through sidequests for my favourite characters, then distributing my worst rolls in a pyramidial manner to characters I like slightly less and so on so forth.


In the world of Disco Sleeper, there's a heavy dearth over the whole universe that capitalism has made things as awful as they are, and I don't mind me a good rage against the machine, hey, I rage against the machine myself too sometimes,

[i]However[/i], 
I do have a problem when its so piss easy to progress in whatever way you want it makes the evil society look ideal. Like in the world of citizen sleeper, you save every minute so you can walk away whenever you want, and there's no consequences for doing absolutely nothing to help yourself. And even moreso everyone is so nice to eachother there's no danger in the world at all. People in mortal bitter rivalries talk out their problems, people steal and get stolen from with no desire for reprisal. The one character that does anything remotely morally questionable immediately renounces her 'evil' (she was in the right btw) ways and decides to abandon her current life for that similar to one of a nun. So its not just the player that all this is just insanely easy for. This world is awesome to live in, this awful world is better to live in than my actual real awful world. If this is the world that the evil capitalists built for the people of Erlin's Eye, sign me up. Sign me up for 2 even, so I can wreck one.

And despite all this, the game was alright. There IS an interesting world and ideas behind all the genera and eye-rolling, I'd buy it on a sale or something if you're willing to live with the big howevers mentioned above.

If you're looking for a similar idea of what you're getting into I'd liken this game to Va1ha11a cyberpunk bartending, where there's an incredibly shallow gameplay mechanic and an incredibly shallow story and they're both smushed together so you don't really realize why neither portion are as good or fleshed out as they could be. | I enjoyed this one quite a bit. More of a visual novel than a typical game.

Pretty good writing but not mind-blowing. The gameplay mechanics are under-developed, especially towards the end they become a bit of a chore. 

But! The story, characters and situations as a whole make up for the flaws. This a very immersive and emotional experience, it really manages to transport you into its world. So overall it's worthwhile.

Game Name: Spirit Swap: Lofi Beats to Match-3 To
Reviews:
Gameplay wise, an excellent articulation of the match-3 games, which is a genre of puzzle that I'm not aware of any coming out in English in the last 5 years,

The music is wonderfully understated and is full of "Mood" pieces that are very easy listening and relaxing encouraging the ability to focus on the game, or setting up on a background monitor as a visualizer to focus on something else.

Buy it. buy it if you loved the Yoshi's Island, or if you enjoyed any version of "Panel-de-pon" that you "acquired" and translated.

one issue to be forewarned about, the Story Mode runs credits after introducing all the characters over a single day, but that's just the beginning of story mode with each character having several levels and scenes where you deepen the friendship. | You beat the main storyline and then you have an option to befriend/romance all the characters. The character design, styles, pronouns, are so diverse that its so refreshing to see a game like this now a days. My only complaint would be that 1. its a very short game. 2. The voice acting is wonderful but there are times where the music overshadows the voices. Other than that its nearly perfect. The actual combat of the game, the puzzles are so refreshing as well and are VERY disability friendly. I have problems with my hands and its nice to have an option to "instant win" instead of t rying over and over and over again and giving up because my hands just dont want to work for days or weeks at a time. It progresses the story along well. 
I've never seen these developers before but I really look forward to some of their future stuff and I wish them the absolute best. Ty for creating such a beautiful piece of work. | [h2] [i]I want to like this game.[/i] [/h2]

As far as the gameplay is concerned, everything there is to love about Panel de Pon / Tetris Attack / Puzzle League is here.
The problem, is if you are any good at this style of gameplay, there's nothing new here. All of your garbage (regardless if it's from a combo or chain) turns into panels when the bottom row is cleared. Therefore, the game is even easier. Even worse, this has the terrible side-effect of completely removing the rhythm expert matches in this style of game have. 
The other thing, is that there are high-level mechanics in PdP/TA/PL that are simply [i]not[/i] possible here. Frame-perfect switching to keep a chain going? Forget about it.

The story mode is nice, it's a puzzle game. I'm not expecting anything groundbreaking, it does what it needs to. However, once you've done that and Versus. That's it. That's the game. Puzzle mode? Line clear? Nowhere to be found. Flipon is $4 and has a puzzle mode. Regardless of price point, missing core mainstays of the genre like this is inexcusable.

It kills me to say this but, grab this while it's on sale. There's a fun couple of hours to be had here for sure if you're new to action puzzle games. However, there's not enough content here for experts and the mechanical changes to core gameplay fundementals take what should be an exciting back and forth and turn it into a speedrun of the boring kind. | Let me be clear: I don't recommend this game in its current state. If there are future updates with story developments and gameplay mechanics I would happily recommend it.

As of right now, I downloaded it the day of release and finished the story in 88 minutes. And the story felt primarily like a pro-longed tutorial where I was learning to swap better and faster, and was being introduced to characters. Mind you, I think the characters are neat (personally would've liked some more mlm rep but that's at the bottom of the barrel of issues), and some of them I was really interested in learning more about. I even was developing some theories to how the story would continue as you went forward, and thinking about how I would write them up to see if I got any correct in the long run...

But the long run never happened. The story was less than 10 versus battles against NPCs who you (the player) just meet for the first time and get a TL;DR of their personality and story. Mind you sometimes that's fine...so long as it would be expanded upon at a later point in the story. (For example, we just found out in this story that [spoiler] Kannon was an Angel, despite us (the character) knowing him for quite some time and him literally looking nothing like the rest of the people in the town and having ACTUAL ANGELIC WINGS [/spoiler]. Facts or information that's given to us isn't given any sense to breathe - its all swapping, some light humor, and then back to swapping. 

I wanted to like this game, hell, I wanted to LOVE this game. I have had it on my wishlist since I was told of this during an Indie Developer E3 Conference in like 2022. I was so excited when I got the notification on my phone that this game finally dropped and I would be able to play. I paid, downloaded it, and was so hyped...for nothing.

I guess I can go back and romance a few options right now, but I don't see a need to do that? The story is done, what more will I learn from these people who aren't going to impact the world around us? If the spirits need swapping are still invading the town, then why are we focusing on dating? Why not get a fuller force to get this completed?

Like I said, if there are future updates with story developments and gameplay mechanics I would happily recommend it to anyone who wants some good vibes and good representation. The music is nice and fitting, the gameplay is smooth and not hard to pick up, and the characters can be interesting and fun to interact with. But it feels like the substance to this game right now is very little and I don't have a desire to go back to it until something else or more gets added. | It's Tetris Attack! But also, it's a little bit of a decorate my house game! But also it's a hang out with cool people game! I'm told there might be kissing!

Vibes a great, team did a fantastic job with the character, audio, and match three. Already looking forward to exploring this more.

Почему Dune: Spice Wars заработала Shiro Games существенно меньше денег, чем Northgard или хотя бы Wartales?

Думаю, дело в следующем:

1. Сложнее въехать (чем в другие работы Shiro). Надо провести хотя бы часов 5-6. И сходу непонятны не только мелкие нюансы, а целые механики.

2. Это не римейк той самой Dune 2. Нет танков, ракетниц, выдуманных Ордосов и много чего ещё. Так уж получилось, что совершенно неканоническая разработка Westwood для многих игроков является первоисточником.

3. Это не особо похоже на Northgard. Вернее, совсем непохоже.

4. Это не RTS, а стратегия 4X. Может быть не такая навороченная как некоторые представители жанра. Но тут точно не работает никакой раш и типовые для RTS подходы.

А теперь то же самое, но с точки зрения плюсов:

1. Что такое 5-6 часов для 4X? Я в своё время в Civ5 въезжал дольше, а в Stellaris окончательно понял как играть через 30 часов. 5-6 часов - просто идеальное время для понимания стратегии такого типа.

2. Shiro гораздо бережнее поработали с книгами. И эта работа с ограничениями заставила их выверять подходы и особенности до мелочей.

3. Если честно, я Spice Wars полгода боялся запускать. Так как думал, что это рескин Northgard с некоторыми наворотами. Ура, это не он!

4. Кому-то вообще нужна была бы Dune 3000? Серьёзно? Жанр устарел ещё в начале 00-х.

А ещё! Здесь редко бывает больше 10-12 юнитов под контролем - и это заставляет включать голову. Общая медлительность позволяет воевать на 2, а иногда даже на 3 фронта. Есть активная пауза (для соло-игры). Дерево развития выверено до мелочей. Стороны сильно отличаются по фишкам. Графика, стиль и вообще UI в целом - идеал.

Короче, отличная игра. Одна из лучших стратегий, в которые я играл за последнее время. | Interesting to begin with.  The game plateaus very quickly though. Very little replayable value for me.  After a couple of hours it gets tedious.  Boring.  I regret buying this game. | The novel Dune was written during the Cold War, and this game has that aura.

Do not expect a standard RTS. This is a game about statecraft, about cold wars, about the balance of power, about paranoia. Warfare is a continuation of policy by other means- often an inevitable one, but more pursued to deny the enemy victory than to seize it. It's more about medieval-style raids & chevauchées than massive campaigns. The Landsraad and intelligence systems are brilliant. Expect assassinations to be a more common threat than sieges of enemy capitals are.

As an adaptation of the novel within the confines of a Civ-style game, it's excellent. The great dangers of Arrakis, the thirst & the worms, are of both strategic & tactical importance- by which I mean they will destroy your entire army if you slip up. So many of the little details of the world are here as well, down to the Fremen donkeys. The factions from the book are invoked wonderfully in gameplay too- the honor and "honor" of the Atreides, the drugged-up thuggery of the Harkonnen troops, the vicious, vampiric fanaticism of the Fremen, the Corrinos lurking aside, playing one House against another until they can throw down a fortress from orbit and seize the planet for themselves. The additional factions are flavorful too.

I'd recommend this game in particular to those who love the book & its cynical philosophy, and to those who like the idea of games like Civ but want something leaner, quicker, & smarter. 

Note that God created the single-player mode to train for the multiplayer mode. This review has assumed that it's the latter you'll be getting the game for. | Feels great. The environment is very dangerous but fair. Politics works, which is impressive for this kind of game. The factions have good differentiation- Harkonnens oppress their people and throw away their own people to feed the machine. Fremen move easily in the desert but they don't get to vote in politics. Atreides can be very effective politcally and can take villages peacefully. And whoever you are, there are the constant pressures of collecting the Spice. | It's too much like the game Civilization and not enough like DUNE 2000.  

It's not a bad game and i can even see how it could have become oddly addicting for many people but for me personally it doesn't really have what i want to satisfy me.  The biggest issue is the lack of strategy involved for how you set up your base/territories.  In fact there is very little actual decision making that goes into your base setup at all.  Instead it's a repetitive process of taking over preexisting villages, then haphazardly placing whatever structures you need around it for that given territory depending on which resources the territory has.  It makes zero strategic difference where you place your buildings because they're never attacked anyway.   It's only the Villages themselves that ever come under threat.. which by the way you defend by repetitively hiring militia for every annex'd village.  In this regard, the game is totally brainless and requires no strategic thinking for how you go about setting up your territories.  In DUNE 2000, for example, there was a very satisfying sense of accomplishment for the way you choose to build your base and design it's defenses.  Spice Wars just doesn't have that.

There is a lot more i could say both negatively and positively about the game but it's mostly the lack of strategy and satisfaction that comes with conquering territories that bothers me.

full game and finished game very rare these days. extremely fun. dont leave your army on a frozen lake and end turn XD | weird, complicated, wild.  The game compensates for the bad graphics with the quality and quantity of weird shenanigans that both happen to you, and that you can choose to get into yourself.  If you can get over the graphics, of course. | This game just has so much depth to it, so many different classes to try and so much hidden complexity to its world. One of my favorite games I've played recently. | A lot of fun and rather easy to take in hand. Really has a nice charm to it! | Perfect asymmetric tabletop-like strategy game with interesting lore and fun gameplay.

The control is a bit unintuitive in the beginning, just like for any other Illwinter games, but once you get used to it, it will become one of those strategy classics you come back to over and over again.

10/10

Anyway this game is pretty solid the music is good 10/10. | If you are in any way shape or form a fan of Hotline Miami: You must get this.

Solid gameplay. Killer soundtrack. Great replay value. Did I mention it plays like Hotline Miami?

There's some fun easter eggs and a fun noir aesthetic that doesn't detract from the language on screen. occasionally had some issues trying to stream the game and had to share the full screen, but otherwise it's my current obsession. |  Игра чем-то напоминает Хотлайн Маями, и геймплееим и стилистикой. Музыка в игре ЭТО ШЕДЕВР просто вот вроде 1 лейтмотив, а звучание обсолютно разное и от того весь саундрек не кажется однообразным! Всем советую эту игру)))

TL;DR I would only recommend this for die-hard Borderlands fans.

The pre-endgame is exceedingly easy despite setting the difficulty to "Intense". I never struggled once up until the end game boss. The most difficult parts of earlier games were the burst damage some enemies did that was hard to overcome as a solo. While I am glad they scaled that back in this game, with no other challenge provided the core loop is reduced to holding down M1 until the enemy dies. To top it off, every quest was just "go here press E, go here shoot this, go here press E". It was a bit disappointing. 

Now admittedly this wouldn't be so egregious if there was a gripping story or moment-to-moment writing like Borderlands 2 had, but personally this game fell very flat in that regard. I listened to every dialogue line and did every side quest expecting at least some moments with the same charm as the previous games, but I didn't find any. Perhaps I have simply become jaded, but there were no hard-hitting lines nor engaging plot lines. I lightly chuckled twice the entire game. I never cringed or wondered what the writers were smoking as I did with BL3, but the Wonderlands plot was simply bland.

This isn't to say the entire game is horrible. I like much of the balance changes they made, the art style is charming, and the class system is interesting. The legendary drop rate is lowered in this game compared to BL3, which was desperately needed as they felt a dime-a-dozen in that game. This is balanced out by having your loot luck increase as you progress in the game which I felt fit very well. The new gun types, the few that aren't recycled from BL3 that is, are fun to play with and a welcome addition. And I appreciate the take on classes with a respeccable second class, although I think I still prefer the per-character system from the mainline games.

Should also be mentioned the end game is potentially the best in a Borderlands game so far: a set of repeatable trial chambers which tie closely into the "Chaos Level" system that increases enemy toughness and unlocks better tiers of gear. I have not completed all the Chaos Levels and won't pretend to have beaten each end game in all BL games, but I would like to say that this feels the most replayable and fair.

Overall a game with fun mechanics that falls entirely flat in the story department. | It's an alright game.

Basic borderlands looter shooter concept, but DnD themed.
Skill trees I feel are less impacting than previous iterations of the game.
You can do a dual class system which I like a lot.
The introduction of companions for most classes is cool, but I feel like they fall pretty short, even when trying to spec into them.
The weapons aren't that much different than other borderlands games. With a difference that you can different melee weapons, and a spell equipped. These are nice twists, and spells can be pretty fun with the variety of options.
The story is kind of dull to be honest. Very heavy in dialogue, which I understand it's a DnD game. But you start to tune out after a while.
The gameplay loop isn't really that exciting. The difficulty is pretty moderate with that you can clear most mobs easily, but then you have to play a little tactfully with others.

Overall I'd say it's worth a heavy discount. Definitely never worth the full asking price.
 | Bisschen lame. Fühlt sich an als würde man kaum etwas sinnvolles tun. Man spielt aber warum? Kein Plan. Ohne meinen Kumpel würde ich mich zu Tode langweilien. Wer krass auf Dnd und Shooter steht ok. Aber wer von der Qualität etwas wie BL3 erwartet wird enttäuscht. | 10/10
Great co-op game for borderlands fans, I'm really happy that they expanded on Tiny Tina's DnD adventure.

However, why are we not releasing any updates at all for this? Not saying to make it a live service game or anything but I'd like to see more content released, or at least an expansion with a raised level cap or something. | 其实我一开始是期待体验会跟无主之地三部曲会有很大不同，结果一进游戏，完了，第一印象就是又回到了那个废土打枪的地方。
但是体验差了很多，因为频繁进出副本打枪，大地图的功能只有赶路，战斗还得额外进副本打，可以说是游戏技术和设计上的巨大退步。

I don't think the vanilla game on it's own is very good.  However, with the added DLCs, it's considerably better.  After that, the mod community has done some exceptional work and added massive amounts of content, quality of life, and performance tweaks that have me seriously hooked.  With all the DLC and the mods, this game is really fun.  

If you want a great preview, check out Baradul on YT.  He's just started another play through as I write this and has a great mods list that just about everyone should enjoy.  I don't care for the heavy smoke and fire effects mod, but check it out anyway, you may dig it.

The Solaris DLC is probably the most flawed of the bunch, but it can be handy to farm decent salvage, C-bills, and weapons early-mid to late game.  In several scenarios, the AI of the mechs in the matches is sketchy at best.  They will just sit still or wander in a tight circle until they spot the player.  Meh.  The campaign for this DLC is funny at least and worth doing.

One bit of warning, enabling all those mods can cause the game load time to crank up to a couple minutes.  Be patient, it's worth the wait.  :) | Recommend with mods. Don't recommend the base game. YAML series of mods make the game worth playing. Along with others. It's the games only redeeming quality, that and the open world mercenary nature of it. Wish a different company would have gotten the license for mechwarrior. | It's a functional game, even pretty fun if you are a fan of the universe, but it has a serious case of needing expansions and mods to really be complete.

It feels like there is a core of good gameplay that is faithful to the setting, but everything else is implemented lazily. Rag dolls don't look right on multi-ton 'mechs, the missions have very procedurally generated feel, even many of the central storyline missions. Also a personal preference, I would prefer a more sim type battles where you go against equal forces most of the time instead of arcadey heroic standoffs where you mow down hordes of enemies. I had to exploit some of the cheesiness inherent of replicating the boardgame in first person style to win some of those fights and didn't love that. I know giant stompy robots aren't realistic, but the setting always pretended it was serious military sci-fi.

Also had to tinker quite a lot to have my preferred controls set up. Luckily someone on Reddit had already done the work and I only had to copy-paste. And I like a bit of tinkering. Reminds me of the old times. Ended up using HOTAM setup. I was also very interested in the VR mod. It is indeed very impressive work but far from perfect. Can't see myself playing the campaign with it. I wish there was native support.

I can't in good conscience recommend this game for an average player. An old Battletech or Mechwarrior fan who's willing to fork more cash for expansions and download a bunch of mods might be an exception. Definitely wait for sales, tho. | Good game, if you can stomach the repetitive missions and the mission design.
By that I mean the enemies are not really difficult to deal with, but they are many... wave after wave can wither you down until you lose expensive/rare components. 

Nevertheless fun for many hours. | Super cool game. I recommend modding the game straight out of the gate and don't even bother with the vanilla game. The rescaling mod is essential. Graphics are OK but with some mods can look great. The game play loop can be repetitive but in this game it works, as you can pick the game up for a few hours but come back anytime you feel like putting in a few more missions. It's kind of like a mech simulator. The fun of the game comes from acquiring new mechs, experimenting with loadouts and upgrading weapons so when you hit the battlefield you feel like a badass. It's built on Unreal engine so there is some unfortunate stutter; for me when enemy lances spawn in and I get the radio message.  The optimisation also leaves a bit to be desired so a fast machine is preferable.

Очень медитативная игра на исследование мира. На 3-4 вечера заставляет забыть обо всём и медленно за чашкой чая исследовать загадки, планировать ресурсы на походы и разбираться в механиках квестов. | В игре много багов (очень), однако это ранний доступ и вроде сам решил играть в недодел, но...  Я мог любые баги потерпеть, но концовку с китайскими субтитрами... ктонить расскажет, что там по итогу рассказывали после того как грохнули скорпиона в конце?

Геймплей в начале был интересным, напомнило Curious Expedition, где каждый шаг стоит провизию, посетить каждую клетку невозможно и проходиться взвешенно выбирать. Разные случайные события, решения которые могут зависеть от инвентаря и навыков персонажей, вобщем всё как мы любим.  А примерно на той стадии, когда открываются дороги между городами, игра с каждой минутой начинала становиться проще и скучнее. 

Боёвки странные, в битве с "равным" противником только скорость твоих персонажей определяет разницу между "весь мой караван сбрили за 1 ход" и "я сбрил всех противников за 1 ход".

Ещё путешествие по дорогам не отменяет наличия "засад", когда между первым и вторым городом на тебя нападают совсем слабые собаки на 1 полутычок, дольше ждёшь загрузку. Это очень нудно. Загрузку на боёвку можно было сделать мгновенную.

Также с некоторого момента ресурсы собираются тоннами, а рюкзак без улучшений по сюжету уж совсем тонкий. Пока сделаешь основные квесты 90% приходится просто выкидывать, чтобы потом получить нормальное расширение рюкзака, но уже перед концом игры =) "для сражения с финальным боссом?". А вообще, если подумать, то ценности ресурсов в игре вообще нет, и весь топовый шмот доступен практически сразу с начала игры. 

И канешн куча непродуманных и сломанных механик, от бесконечного фарма ресурсов на бесплатных дорогах, до читерного хила, который позволяет в некоторых случаях обходиться без провизии - получать урон при передвижении, а при очередной стычке выхиливать отряд на полную и продолжать своё непобедимое и голодное шествие.

В конечном итоге сложилось впечатление, что единственный кто старался над проектом это художник, ведь графика в игре, в отличии от всего остального, действительно красивая.

This game is very badly balanced, designed and buggy to boot. I gave it time to see if updates fixed it but nope still a mess like on release.

giant laundry list of issues:
1) Weapon balance makes 0 sense. but that doesn't mater because..
2) Weapons are useless. All you need is a high damage weapon then the time slowdown and autoaim powers can play the game for you. manually shooting at stuff is a mess when you die in a second if you stop moving like a monkey because most enemies are hitscan and you die the millisecond you stop jumping / dashing.
3) Have to execute enemies in melee nonstop to heal while waiting your broken powers to recharge. The animations glitch out more often than they work properly and half of them are over 3 seconds long.
4) Calling the story garbage is like pretending it has one. the story you get to play feels like an over-extended prologue for a real game story.
5) The graphics glitch out especially in the last few missions.
6) Everywhere looks the same. You'll spend the entire time in ugly tunnels, sometimes the game baits you with what looks like a giant city then nope back to the tunnels for you.
7) There is like 5 enemy types and outside the rocket mechs non of them qualify for more than fodders in other games.
8) Your dog is a timed summon that gives you wallhacks; it can jump around why does it need to constantly disappear?
9) The loot barely makes a difference and you will probably benefit more just selling it all to get upgraded biotechs anyway. aside from archeotech (damage boost per bullet) if you want to break the dps limits with a minigun.
10) The gundealer is completely useless, wasn't useful a single time in the entire campaign.
11) The bounties are just dumb random missions in areas you've already played, like running around to kill 10 witches in a 20 meter room while enemies indefinitely spawn.
12) Music bugs out all the time.

The main issue I have with the game is what it focuses on which is the combat, it feels like they really wanted to make a Doom-like shooter but all it ended up with is a weak watered down version of Doom with lazy and/or unfinished aspects of the game and a 40k coat of paint. Also they turned the Doom gameplay into a cover shooter for some reason. But the most glaring issue I've seen is the laughable animations, the characters move like first generation console characters. All in all there is really just no reason to play this game, no matter how much you like 40k, just save your time and money and stay away from this one.
